etymologies: early 17th century: from medieval Latin quota (pars) ‘how great (a part)’, feminine of quotus, from quot ‘how many’

definitions: a fixed share of something that a person or group is entitled to receive or is bound to contribute

examples.text: the county is falling short of its quota of blood donations

definitions: a limited quantity of a particular product which under official controls can be produced, exported, or imported

examples.text: the country may be exceeding its OPEC quota of 1,100,000 barrels of oil per day

shortDefinitions: limited quantity of particular product which under official controls can be produced or imported

definitions: a fixed minimum or maximum number of a particular group of people allowed to do something, such as immigrants to enter a country, workers to undertake a job, or students to enroll for a course

examples.text: the removal of entry quotas encouraged young people to enter universities
they demanded a quota for women on the committee

shortDefinitions: fixed number of group of people allowed to do something

definitions: (in a system of proportional representation) the minimum number of votes required to elect a candidate.
shortDefinitions: (in system of proportional representation) minimum number of votes required to elect candidate

definitions: a person's share of a particular thing, quality, or attribute

examples.text: an Irishman with a double ration of blarney and a treble quota of charm

shortDefinitions: person's share of particular thing or attribute
